Award.AwardTitle: Conference: 18th International Conference on the Cell and Molecular Biology of Chlamydomonas to be held June, 2018, Washington, DC
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support attendance by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers at the 18th International Conference on the Cell and Molecular Biology of Chlamydomonas, to be held June 17-21, 2018 at the Carnegie Institution in Washington, DC. The meeting will start with a public forum emphasizing the utility of the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas as a model for studying biology in complex organisms. Formal sessions will include a combination of plenary lectures, talks and poster sessions. There will be ample opportunity for sharing latest research results and for exploring collaborative possibilities.

Chlamydomonas is an outstanding model for understanding many biological processes. Recent advances in the field, including new technological capabilities, will be highlighted in this meeting. Among the topics for discussion will be structure and function of flagella; plastid structure, function and biogenesis; carbon metabolism; cell cycle, photoperception, heat and circadian control; novel studies and developing systems; and recently developed resources for reverse genetics. The meeting will bring together seasoned investigators with early-career scientists in a venue that will encourage informal discussion and sharing of latest research results.

This award is co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms, Cellular Dynamics and Function, and Systems and Synthetic Biology Clusters in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Physiological Mechanisms and Biomechanics Program in the Physiological and Structural Systems Cluster of the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, all of which are in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This funds awarded supported the organization of the 18th International Conference on the Cellular and Molecular Biology of Chlamydomonas. Studies of this photosynthetic, model organism (alga) are highly relevant to our understanding of a diversity of biological processes including photosynthetisis (the utilization of the energy in sunlight) and the production of food, fuel and neutraceutical products. Examining aspects of the ways in which this organism moves and senses its surroundings has also contributed to our understanding of certain human diseases.  

This meeting, which had about 200 participants, was focused on promoting interactions among investigators, with an emphasis on the work and career paths of young scientists. The format of the meeting included an evening public talk, three plenary lectures and over 40 presentations of between 10 and 30 min in structured, topic-oriented sessions. There was also a workshop and poster sessions (with 119 posters); the latter were maintained for viewing throughout the meeting. This format allowed for very effective and stimulating interactions, fostered debate among participants at all stages in their career, and minimizied competition among the groups. The public talk was attended by over three hundred people, which nearly filled the lecture hall. The speaker, Susan Dutcher, received many questions from the general public on the role of photosynthetic organisms in the nation's future research goals, especially with respect to potential 'human benefits'. 

Furthermore, the meeting helped disseminated the Chlamydomonas knowledge base and elicited enthusiastic and dynamic interactions among young investigators, which led to discussions of the development of transformative discoveries that will contribute to shaping our future global society. The diversity of talks included descriptions of key new technologies, methods to edit genes and modulate outputs of biosynthetic pathways, schemes for boosting photosynthesis and the fixation of carbon into sugars, polysaccharides and oils, research that is allowing us to decipher mechanisms that enable organisms to adapt to environmental change (which is important in the rapidly changing environment of our planet) and  insights into specific human maladies. A very satisfying outcome of the conference was the development of numerous interactions that helped to integrate participants with complementary interests and expertise, leading to the initiation of collaborative efforts. This conference is the major international forum for Chlamydomonas research, and the communications fostered during the conference are currently setting directions and the pace of our scientific future.
